title: BE / BEING / BEEN — Structured Lesson
subtitle: Structure → Example → Short explanation. Content mirrors the provided transcript.

sections.heading: Forms of the Verb "BE"
sections.explanation: "Be" follows the same pattern as other verbs (eat/ate/eaten, go/went/gone). It has distinct present and past forms.

sections.heading: BEING — Present / Past Continuous
examples: He was being taught how to tie his shoes.
sections.explanation: "Being" functions like other -ing verbs in continuous tenses. In the second example, the phrase is passive continuous (was being taught).

sections.heading: BEING — Gerund (Noun Use)
structure: Being + noun/adjective phrase → used as subject or object
examples: Being an online English teacher is amazing.
sections.explanation: "Being" acts as a gerund (a noun). It can function as the subject of the sentence.

sections.heading: BEEN — Perfect Tenses (Overview)
examples: I will have been to Germany by next year.
sections.explanation: "Been" is the past participle used in perfect tenses to indicate experiences or actions completed before a reference time.

sections.heading: BE — After Modal Verbs
examples: You should wear green more often.
sections.explanation: After modal verbs, use the base form (be). Do not insert 'to' after modals.

sections.heading: BE — Infinitive Form
examples: I want to be just like you.
sections.explanation: "To be" is the infinitive. Certain verbs commonly take the infinitive form after them.

sections.heading: BE — Subjunctive
examples: The teacher recommended that he be put in a higher reading group.
sections.explanation: In subjunctive constructions the verb does not change for person or number; it remains 'be'.

sections.heading: Passive Voice — Be / Being / Been
structure: be-form + verb3 (be / being / been + past participle)
examples: Our windows will be washed next week.
sections.explanation: Passive voice uses the appropriate form of 'be' according to tense, followed by the past participle (verb 3). Use passive when the doer is unimportant or unknown.

summary.example: I want to be a singer.
